comments.body:
Could we instead use the Python `logging` module to still log the exception thrown by `read_csv` instead of swallowing it, e.g. as recommended [in this StackOverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/31444861/12111347)? In particular if we configure a logger at the top of the file via:

```
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.WARN)
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
```

We can use it here via:
```
try:
    raise Exception("awef")
except Exception as e:
    logger.exception("Unable to download training & test CSV, check your internet connection. Error: %s", e)
```

Is this correct?
```
try:
     data = pd.read_csv('http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/wine-quality/winequality-red.csv', sep=';')
    
except Exception as e:
        logger.exception("Unable to download training & test CSV, check your internet connection. Error: %s", e)
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +38,42 @@    try:
        data = pd.read_csv(csv_url, sep=';')
    except Exception as e:
        logger.exception(
            "Unable to download training & test CSV, check your internet connection. Error: %s", e)
